Title: Synthesis and characterization of copolymers from acrylic and methacrylic acid with 2‐methylaziridine by spontaneous copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Methylaziridine (MAz) as a nucleophilic monomer and acrylic acid (AA) and methacrylic acid (MA), respectively, as electrophilic monomers were copolymerized in the absence of initiator at various feed ratios. Copolymers were characterized by elemental analysis, FT‐IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined by the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdős methods. Values of r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were found to be less than unity for MAz‐AA, and MAz‐MA, corresponding to random copolymers with the tendency to the alternance. For all the copolymers the thermal decomposition with 10% weight loss is higher than 430 K. The reaction order for degradation of all copolymers was zero. The kinetic parameters of the decomposition were determined for all copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Free‐radical copolymerization of 2‐[3‐(6‐tetralino)‐3‐methylcyclobutyl]‐2‐ketoethyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile and styrene: Synthesis, characterization, and monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of the monomer 2‐[3‐(6‐tetralino)‐3‐methylcyclobutyl]‐2‐ketoethyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile and styrene was carried out in a 1,4‐dioxane solution at 60°C with 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as an initiator. The copolymers were characterized with Fourier transform infrared, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR, and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectroscopy techniques. The thermal properties of the polymers were also studied with thermogravimetric analysis and differential scanning calorimetry. The copolymer compositions were determined with elemental analysis and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR techniques. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by the application of conventional linearization methods (Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdös) to be less than 1 for both monomers. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 104: 1979–1986, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Analysis of the linear methods of determining copolymerization reactivity ratios, 11. Copolymerization of styrene with methyl α‐cyanocinnamate and fumaroyldipyrrolidone
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The composition of copolymers was determined as a function of the monomer feed for two systems: styrene/methyl <jats:italic>a</jats:italic>‐cyanocinnamate in toluene and styrene/fumaroyldipyrrolidone in dimethyl sulfoxide both at 60°C with 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. To ascertain the accuracy of reaction modelling in terms of the classical and the penultimate model, the extended linearized forms of both models were applied. The styrene/methyl <jats:italic>a</jats:italic>‐cyanocinnamate system was found to copolymerize non‐classically; the two‐parameter penultimate model described properly the experimental data yielding <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>'<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ≈ 3–6. The styrene/fumaroyldipyrrolidone system showed only a slight penultimate effect. However, in this case, the terminal model gave a better fit of experimental data.</jats:p>

Title: The Reactivity Ratios of Acrylonitrile Copolymerization
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Synthesis and Characterization of Organotin Containing Copolymers: Reactivity Ratio Studies
Abstract: <jats:p>Organotin monomers containing dibutyltin groups – dibutyltin citraconate (DBTC) as a new monomer and dibutyltin maleate (DBTM) – were synthesized. Free radical copolymerizations of the organotin monomers with styrene (ST) and butyl acrylate (BA) were performed. The overall conversion was kept low (≤15% wt/wt) for all studied samples and the copolymers composition was determined from tin analysis using the Gillman and Rosenberg method. The reactivity ratios were calculated from the copolymer composition using the Fineman-Ross (FR) method. The synthesized monomers were characterized by elemental analysis, 1H-, 13C-NMR and FTIR spectroscopy.</jats:p>

Title: Radiation‐induced copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with vinyl ethers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radiation‐induced copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with various vinyl ethers has been studied. It was found that tetrafluoroethylene can be copolymerized with vinyl ethers to give alternating copolymers over a wide range of the initial monomer concentration in the monomer mixture. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined for the copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl vinyl ether as 0.005 (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>TFE</jats:sub>) and 0.0015 (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>NBVE</jats:sub>). The rate of copolymerization is extremely high and has a maximum at an equimolar concentration of two monomers. The alternating structure of the copolymers was confirmed by the analysis of NMR spectra. Some thermal properties of the copolymers were measured by DSC and DTA.</jats:p>

Title: Cationic polymerization and copolymerization of vinylferrocene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Vinylferrocene was shown to undergo readily cationic polymerization by FRIEDEL‐CRAFTS and other cationic catalysts. The polymers obtained possessed rather low molecular weights, the highest being 3500. In spite of the high reactivity of the ferrocene nucleus towards electrophilic substitution, no mode of propagation other than vinyl addition was detected when the infrared spectra of polymers prepared by cationic and free radical reactions were compared. The electronic spectra of polyvinylferrocene and its oxidized form were similar to those of ferrocene and ferricinium ion, respectively. In the cationie copolymerization with styrene, the latter was incorporated into the polymer only when the styrene content in the monomer feed exceeded 90%. The copolymerization with vinyl isobutyl ether (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) by BF<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>OEt<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in toluene at 0°C gave the reactivity ratios: r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.1 ± 0.1, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 9.7 ± 1.0. The high cationic reactivity of vinylferrocene is consistent with the stability of the α‐ferrocenylearbonium ion inferred from solvolysis and other reactions.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of butadiene and vinylferrocene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical copolymerization of butadiene and vinylferrocene was studied at 60°C in 1,4‐dioxane. Copolymerization occurs readily to give low molecular weight random copolymers. The reactivity ratios are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (butadiene) = 3,5±0,5 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (vinylferrocene) = 0,30±0,10 and the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for vinylferrocene are 0,68 and −1,05, respectively. The copolymers are shown to contain a paramagnetic species which is identified as a high spin Fe(III) complex.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of Reactivity Ratios of N-butyl Acrylate/methyl Methacrylate Copolymerization by NMR Spectroscopy
Abstract: <jats:p>In this study, the reactivity ratios of n-butyl acrylate (BA) and methyl methacrylate (MMA) were investigated. The copolymerization reactions were performed in toluene at 70 oC, using azobisisobutyronitrile as the initiator. The composition of the initial monomer mixture and copolymers was easily determined with the help of proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H-NMR) spectroscopy. The molar fractions of BA and MMA in the feed were varied to apply the linear methods of Fineman–Ross and Kelen - Tudos. The calculation gave the reactivity ratios   and  . The computed copolymer composition was relatively close to the real copolymers obtained, with a 5% deviation.</jats:p>

Title: Nitrogen‐containing monomers. I. Copolymerization reactions of N‐alkyl maleamic acids and N‐alkyl maleimides
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The polymerization reactions of some <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐alkyl maleamic acids and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐alkyl maleimides have been described and a number of copolymers have been characterized. The <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐alkyl maleamic acids do not homopolymerize under the conditions employed but do copolymerize with styrene, acrylonitrile, and methacrylates. <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐Alkyl maleimides form homopolymers readily and copolymerize with a variety of vinyl monomers. Reactivity ratios of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐butyl maleimide with styrene and methyl methacrylate have been determined, and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values have been calculated.</jats:p>

Title: Study of Copolymerization Acrylamide with Methyl Methacrylate
Abstract:
<jats:p>Copolymer of acrylamide (AM) with methyl methacrylate (MMA) was synthesized by free radical technique using dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) as solvent and benzoyl peroxide (BPO) as initiator. The overall conversion was kept low (≤ 15% wt/wt) for all studies copolymer’s samples. The synthesized copolymers were characterized using fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and their thermal properties were studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The copolymers compositions were determined by elemental analysis. The monomer reactivity ratios have been calculated by linearization methods proposed by Kelen-Tudos and Fineman-Ross. The derived reactivity ratios (r1, r2) for (AM-co-MMA) are: (0.03, 0.593). The microstructure of copolymers and sequence distribution of monomers in the copolymers were calculated by statistical method based on the average reactivity ratios and found that these values are in agreement with the derived reactivity ratios. Copolymers of AM with MMA formed alternating copolymers.

Keywords: Acrylamide; Methyl methacrylate; Reactivity ratios; Sequence distribution</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylamide and styrene. II. Reactivity ratios with unperturbed acrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>It was reported earlier that the copolymerization of acrylamide and styrene is strongly affected by the copolymerization medium. The effect was attributed to a change in the polarity of the ethylenic bond in the acrylamide monomer due to hydrogen bonding and/or dipole—dipole interaction, depending on the medium. In view of those findings, it was suggested that absolute values for the reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of these two monomers might be obtained only when the acrylamide monomer is unperturbed. Copolymerizations of these monomers at a number of ratios, therefore, were done in benzene, which does not undergo hydrogen bonding and has no dipole moment, at high dilution, when amide—amide interactions between acrylamide molecules should be essentially eliminated. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = acrylamide) were 9.14 ± 0.27 and 0.67 ± 0.08, respectively. There appears to be some indication in this system that high dilution adversely affects the reactivity of the acrylamide monomer while enhancing that of styrene. This aspect requires more study.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics of free‐radical copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene and styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene and styrene has been studied in toluene and dimethyl phthalate solutions at 60°C. Gas chromatography was used to monitor the rate of consumption of monomers. For styrene alone, the measured rate of polymerization <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the polymer coincided with values expected from previous studies by other workers. Solution viscosity η affected <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub> of styrene homopolymers and copolymers as expected on the basis of an inverse proportionality between η<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> and termination rate. The rate of initiation by azobisisobutyronitrile appears to be independent of monomer feed composition in this system. Molecular weights of copolymers can be accounted for by considering combinative termination only. The effects of radical chain transfer are not significant.</jats:p><jats:p>A theory is proposed in which the rate of termination of copolymer radicals is derived statistically from an ideal free‐radical polymerization model. This simple theory accounts quantitatively for <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub> data reported here and for the results of other workers who have favored more complicated reaction models because of the apparent failure of simple copolymer reactivity ratios to predict polymer composition. This deficiency results from systematic losses of low molecular weight copolymer species in some analyses. Copolymer reactivity ratios derived with the assumption of a simple copolymer model and based on rates of monomer loss can be used to predict <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> values measured in other laboratories without necessity for consideration of depropagation or penultimate unit effects. The 60°C rate constants for propagation and termination in styrene homopolymerization were taken to be 176 and 2.7 × 10<jats:sup>7</jats:sup> mole/l.‐sec, respectively. The corresponding figures for α‐methylstyrene are 26 and 8.1 × 10<jats:sup>8</jats:sup> mole/l.‐sec. These constants account for the sluggish copolymerization behavior of the latter monomer and the low molecular weights of its copolymers. The simple reaction scheme proposed here suggests that high molecular weight styrene–α‐methylstyrene copolymers can be produced at reasonable rates at 60°C by emulsion polymerization. This is shown to be the case.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of allyl esters of some fatty acids
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Attempts have been made unsuccessfully to homopolymerize a number of allyl esters of substituted fatty acids by radical initiation in emulsion systems. Copolymerizations of these allyl esters with styrene, methyl methacrylate, and vinyl chloride have been investigated. Of these comonomers, styrene and methyl methacrylate do not copolymerize well with the allyl esters, whereas vinyl chloride does. Reactivity ratios for the radical copolymerization of allyl 11‐iodoundecanoate, M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, and vinyl chloride, M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, determined at 60°C. in benzene, are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.42 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.64. A copolymer of allyl 10, 11‐dibromoundecanoate and vinyl chloride was fractionated and found to be fairly homogeneous.</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerization of cyanomethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of cyanomethyl methacrylate (CyMA) homopolymerization was investigated in acetonitrile with azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The rate of polymerization <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> was expressed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.49</jats:sup>[CyMA]<jats:sup>1.2</jats:sup> and the overall activation energy was calculated as 72.3 kJ/mol. Kinetic constants for CyMA polymerization were obtained as follows: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:03606376:media:POL170211015:tex2gif-stack-1" /> = 0.10 L<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup>s<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>; 2<jats:italic>fk</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>d</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 1.57 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup>s<jats:sup>−</jats:sup>. The relative reactivity ratios of CyMA(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.15, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.29) and methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.43, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.75) in acetonitrile were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme (in styrene copolymerization) led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 1.64 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.98. The glass transition temperature <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub> of poly(CyMA) was observed to be 91°C by thermomechanical analysis. Thermogravimetry of poly(CyMA) showed a 10% weight loss at 265°C in air.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios for new copolymerizations relevant to thermosetting resins
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free radical copolymerizations of four new systems, namely (1) methyl methacrylate (MMA) with β‐acryloxypropionic acid (AOPA); (2) MMA with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐styrene sulphonyl chloride (SSC); (3) 2‐[(phenylamino) carbonyl] oxyethyl methacrylate (PCOMA) with 2‐phenoxyethyl methacrylate (PEMA); and (4) PCOMA with 1‐methyl‐2‐phenoxyethyl methacrylate (MPEMA), have been carried out at 60°C for systems 1 and 2 and at 70°C for systems 3 and 4. The copolymer compositions were analysed by acid‐base titration for system 1 and by FTIR for systems 2–4. The monomer reactivity ratios as well as the 95% individual confidence intervals and 95% joint confidence intervals were calculated from the Kelen‐Tüdős method, the Extended Kelen‐Tüdőos method, and from a new iterative linear method by Mao and Huglin. The results show that all these copolymerizations are strictly linear systems describable by the Mayo‐Lewis equation based on the terminal model and that accurate reactivity ratio data can be obtained. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of the monomers AOPA and SSC have been estimated. Some physical properties of AOPA, PEMA and MPEMA are also presented for the first time.</jats:p>

Title: An improved method of calculating copolymerization reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A nonlinear least‐squares method for solving for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> the copolymerization reactivity ratios, is explained. This new method is superior to all other methods that have been used heretofore in the following ways: (<jats:italic>1</jats:italic>) a unique pair of values is obtained which does not depend on the judgment of the person examining the data; (<jats:italic>2</jats:italic>) this pair of values can be shown mathematically to be the best pair obtainable from the data at hand; (<jats:italic>3</jats:italic>) the errors are quantitatively defined in meaningful terms: and (<jats:italic>4</jats:italic>) the data are checked to see how well they fit the copolymer equation. A basis for selecting experimental conditions which will provide data from which precise values of the reactivity ratios can be obtained is explained, and experimental conditions appropriate for obtaining these precise values over a wide range of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values are presented in tabular form.</jats:p>

Title: Organotin polymers XIV. Synthesis and copolymerization reactions of p‐acryloyloxy‐tri‐n‐butyltin benzoate with some vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>p‐Acryloyloxy‐tri‐n‐butyltin benzoate (ABTB) was prepared by the reaction of p‐hydroxy‐tri‐n‐butyltin benzoate and acrylic acid in the presence of dicyclohexylcarbodiimide. The monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerizations of ABTB (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with methyl acrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), ethyl acrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), n‐butyl acrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) and acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) have been found to be r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.080, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.046; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.039, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.585; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.019, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.076; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.150, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.710; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.113, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.339 and r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.007, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.853, respectively. The Q and e values for the prepared organotin monomer were calculated. Copolymerization reactions were carried out in solution at 70°C using 1 mol‐% azobisisobutyronitrile. The structure of the ABTB monomer and the prepared copolymers was investigated by IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy.</jats:p>

Title: COPOLYMERIZATION OF METHYL METHACRYLATE WITH 2-METHYLBENZYL METHACRYLATE AND 4-METHYLBENZYL METHACRYLATE: SYNTHESIS, CHARACTERIZATION, AND MONOMER REACTIVITY RATIOS
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of N‐(4‐bromophenyl)‐2‐methacrylamide with n‐butyl methacrylate: Synthesis, characterization and monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(4‐bromophenyl)‐2‐methacrylamide (BrPMAAm) has been synthesized by reacting 4‐bromoaniline with methacryloyl chloride in the presence of triethylamine (NR<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) at 0−5°C. Copolymerization of BrPMAAm with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BMA) has been carried out in 1,4‐dioxane by free radical solution polymerization at (70 ± 0.1)°C utilizing 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator in different in‐feed ratios. The composition of the copolymer was determined by the elemental analysis. The comonomer reactivity ratios determined by Fineman‐Ross (FR), Kelen‐Tüdös (KT), and extended Kelen‐Tüdös (EKT) methods. The copolymers were characterized by FTIR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐, and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectroscopic technique. Gel permeation chromatography was employed for estimating the weight–average (<jats:styled-content><jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content><jats:sub><jats:italic>w</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and number–average (<jats:styled-content><jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content><jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub>) molecular weights and polydispersity index (PDI) of the copolymers. Glass transition temperatures (<jats:italic>T<jats:sub>g</jats:sub></jats:italic>) were determined by differential scanning calorimetry and found to be characteristic of copolymer composition. As the <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(4‐bromophenyl)‐2‐methacrylamide content increases, the <jats:italic>T<jats:sub>g</jats:sub></jats:italic> increases from 339 to 437 K. Thermal stabilities of the homo‐ and copolymers were calculated using thermogravimetric analysis. Thermally stable copolymers were obtained by the incorporation of BrPMAAm units as the initial decomposition temperature of the copolymers increased with the increase in concentration of BrPMAAm units. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2008</jats:p>

Title: Atom transfer radical homo‐ and copolymerization of styrene and methyl acrylate initiated with trichloromethyl‐ terminated poly(vinyl acetate) macroinitiator: A kinetic study
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Atom transfer radical bulk copolymerization of styrene (St) and methyl acrylate (MA) initiated with trichloromethyl‐terminated poly(vinyl acetate) macroinitiator was performed in the presence of CuCl/PMDETA as a catalyst system at 90°C. Linear dependence of ln[M]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>/[M] versus time data along with narrow polydispersity of molecular weight distribution revealed that all the homo‐ and copolymerization reactions proceed according to the controlled/living characteristic. To obtain more reliable monomer reactivity ratios, the cumulative average copolymer composition at moderate to high conversion was determined by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. Reactivity ratios of St and MA were calculated by the extended Kelen‐Tudos (KT) and Mao‐Huglin (MH) methods to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 1.018 ± 0.060, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0.177 ± 0.025 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 1.016 ± 0.053, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0.179 ± 0.023, respectively, which are in a good agreement with those reported for the conventional free‐radical copolymerization of St and MA. Good agreement between the theoretical and experimental composition drifts in the comonomer mixture and copolymer as a function of the overall monomer conversion were observed, indicating that the reactivity ratios calculated by copolymer composition at the moderate to high conversion are accurate. Instantaneous copolymer composition curve and number‐average sequence length of comonomers in the copolymer indicated that the copolymerization system tends to produce a random copolymer. However, MA‐centered triad distribution results indicate that the spontaneous gradient copolymers can also be obtained when the mole fraction of MA in the initial comonomer mixture is high enough. © 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2009</jats:p>

Title: High-pressure free-radical copolymerization of ethene-methacrylic acid and of ethene-acrylic acid, 1. (Meth)acrylic acid reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Radical polymerization in the presence of complexing agents. II. Copolymerization of methyl methacrylate‐allyl methacrylate in the presence of zinc chloride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA)‐allyl methacrylate (AMA) in the presence of zinc chloride, using azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator has been carried out. The copolymerization rate increases with the concentration of ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and the reactivity ratios are modified by the concentration of ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> which is explained by the different tendency towards the formation of complexes between MMA and AMA with ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Polymerizable derivatives of long‐chain fatty acids. VII. Copolymerization of vinyl acetate with some long‐chain vinyl esters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A study was made of the copolymerization of vinyl acetate with vinyl palmitate, vinyl stearate, and vinyl oleate, respectively, True copolymerization was shown to have occurred on the basis of the solubility characteristics of the crude copolymers over a wide range of compositions. The monomer reactivity ratios for the comonomers vinyl palmitate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and vinyl acetate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were determined by two methods. One, based on an analysis of the copolymer, gave <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.78 ± 0.10 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.15 ± 0.13; the other, based on an analysis for each monomer in the mixture remaining after polymerization, gave <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.66 ± 0.07 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.84 ± 0.10. When the vinyl palmitate or vinyl stearate content of the copolymer exceeded about 20–25 mole per cent, the copolymers exhibited first‐order transition points which were determined using a refractive index technique as well as a polarizing microscope method. Where no transition point could be observed, brittle point measurements were made.</jats:p>

Title: Graft Copolymerization of Pyrrolidone onto Copolymers of N-Acryloyl Pyrrolidone and Vinyl Monomers
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios in copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free radical copolymerization of two monomers is usually described in terms of reactivity ratios, only two of which are needed for the simplest (Mayo‐Lewis) model. Other, more complex models (such as penultimate unit effects or complex formation) require more kinetic parameters for a complete description. Published summaries of reactivity ratios list values for about 700 monomers taken from more than 1400 publications. These values represent an enormous amount of descriptive and physico‐chemical information about copolymerization in particular and free radical reactivity in general. It is important that we understand the limits to the numerical correctness of existing data, and that future data gathering be done in a statistically correct manner. In this paper several different linear and non‐linear regression approaches to estimating reactivity ratios are reviewed with emphasis being placed on the Mayo‐Lewis model. Two separate problems are recognized: the first is that of model discrimination, the second that of parameter estimation. It is rare that both problems can be properly treated with a single set of experiments, and we discuss the experimental approaches needed to obtain statistically good results.</jats:p>

Title: Unexpected alternating radical copolymerization of chlorotrifluoroethylene with 3‐isopropenyl‐α,α′‐dimethylbenzyl isocyanate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical solution copolymerization of hexafluoropropylene, chlorotrifluoroethylene (CTFE), vinylidene fluoride, and <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl‐α‐trifluoromethylacrylate with different monomers bearing isocyanato groups such as allyl isocyanate, 3‐isopropenyl‐α,α′‐dimethylbenzyl isocyanate (<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI), and 2‐isocyanatoethyl methacrylate, initiated by 2,5‐bis(<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butylperoxy)‐2,5‐dimethylhexane were studied. Several of these radical copolymerizations were not successful in contrast to that of CTFE with <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI, although <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI monomer does not homopolymerize under radical initiation. The resulting poly(CTFE‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI) copolymers were characterized by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H and <jats:sup>19</jats:sup>F nuclear magnetic resonance and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and their compositions assessed by elemental analysis. The reactivity ratios of both comonomers were determined by linearization methods of Fineman‐Ross, Kelen‐Tüdös for low conversions of monomers, and by the extended Kelen‐Tüdös method for high monomer conversions. The average values of the monomer reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>CTFE</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI</jats:sub>, were 0.076 and 0.034 at 130 °C, respectively, depending on these monomer conversions and the applied methods of calculation. In all cases, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>CTFE</jats:sub> × <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI</jats:sub> product was close to zero, which indicates that poly(CTFE‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI) copolymers exhibit a high tendency toward alternation. This was also confirmed by the Igarashi's theory which revealed a high content of CTFE‐<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐MTI heterodyads. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI monomer were also assessed (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI</jats:sub> = 0.007 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐TMI</jats:sub> = 0.99). As well as this kinetics of copolymerization, several properties of the obtained fluorofunctional copolymers such as molecular weights (ranging from 1500 to 8200 g mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>), molecular weight distributions (from 1.2 to 2.1) were also investigated. Their thermal properties revealed satisfactory thermal stability (higher than 250 °C). © 2010 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 48: 2681–2697, 2010</jats:p>

Title: Graft polymers with macromonomers. II. Copolymerization kinetics of methacrylate‐terminated polystyrene and predicted graft copolymer structures
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization studies of methacrylate‐terminated polystyrene macromonomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with several comonomers (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) verified the modified kinetic scheme and permitted prediction of graft polymer compositions and structures. Instantaneous and cumulative copolymer compositions, average graft distributions, and grafts per molecule are predicted from FORTRAN IV or BASIC programs. The <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> relative reactivity ratios determined from styrene copolymerization (0.61) or from low conversion acrylic monomer in aqueous suspension (∼0.4) had good agreement with literature values (about 0.6 and 0.4, respectively). Decreased macromonomer reactivity determined at high acrylic monomer conversions was attributed to phase separation phenomena. The Macromers also exhibited lower reactivity than predicted when copolymerized with acrylic monomers in DMSO/benzene solutions (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ∼ 0.8).</jats:p>

Title: Electron exchange polymers. XIX. Copolymerization behavior of vinylhydroquinone dibenzoate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization behavior of vinylhydroquinone dibenzoate monomer (VHDB), in solution under free radical initiator conditions, with styrene, α‐methylstyrene, 4‐vinylpyridine, methyl methacrylate, and methyl acrylate, to less than 10% conversion, showed good copolymerizabilities with these conventional monomers. Rates of polymerization are greater in VHDB‐rich monomer compositions in spite of the bulky character of the benzoyl group. <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> values (Alfrey and Price) are given. The resonance term (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) for VHDB is near unity, which seems to indicate that the resonance effect in stabilizing the radical is almost as large as that of styrene The polarity term, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, is assigned a positive value for VHDB. Ultraviolet absorption spectra of the copolymers imply neighboring group interactions in the copolymer chains—interactions implied by the observed <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> values, and implied in earlier work by electrometric titration behavior.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of styrene. II. Emulsion copolymerization with styrene derivatives containing nitrile groups in the side chain
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of styrene with cinnamonitrile, ethyl benzylidenecyanoacetate, and benzylidenemalononitrile were prepared in emulsion with the use of the redox system potassium persulfate–sodium bisulfite. The kinetics of copolymerization as a function of the composition of monomers, of the concentration of emulsifier and initiators, and of temperature was studied. Copolymers of high molecular weight were obtained in good yields.</jats:p>

Title: Studying Reactivity Relationships of Copolymers N-naphthylacrylamide with (Acrylicacid and Methylacrylate)
Abstract: <jats:p>            The organation ⁄monomer N-naphthylacrylamide (NAA) was prepared; subsequently the synthesized monomer was successfully copolymerized with acrylicacid (AA) and methylacrylate (MA) by free radical technique using dry benzene as solvent and benzoyl peroxide (BPO) as initiator. The overall conversion was kept low (≤ 10% wt/wt) for all studies copolymers samples. The synthesized monomer and copolymers were characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and their thermal properties were studied by DSC and TGA. The copolymers compositions were determined by elemental analysis. Kelen-Tudes and Finmman-Ross graphical procedures were employed to determine the monomers reactivity ratios. The derived reactivity ratios (r1, r2) are: (0.048, 0.687) for (NAA-co-AA) and (0.066, 0.346) for (NAA-co-MA). Based on the average reactivity ratios, sequence distribution of monomers in the copolymers and the microstructure of copolymers were calculated by statistical method and found that these values are in agreement with the derived reactivity ratios.</jats:p>

Title: Studying Reactivity Relationships of Copolymers N-naphthylacrylamide with (Acrylicacid and Methylacrylate)
Abstract: <jats:p>            The organation ⁄monomer N-naphthylacrylamide (NAA) was prepared; subsequently the synthesized monomer was successfully copolymerized with acrylicacid (AA) and methylacrylate (MA) by free radical technique using dry benzene as solvent and benzoyl peroxide (BPO) as initiator. The overall conversion was kept low (≤ 10% wt/wt) for all studies copolymers samples. The synthesized monomer and copolymers were characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and their thermal properties were studied by DSC and TGA. The copolymers compositions were determined by elemental analysis. Kelen-Tudes and Finmman-Ross graphical procedures were employed to determine the monomers reactivity ratios. The derived reactivity ratios (r1, r2) are: (0.048, 0.687) for (NAA-co-AA) and (0.066, 0.346) for (NAA-co-MA). Based on the average reactivity ratios, sequence distribution of monomers in the copolymers and the microstructure of copolymers were calculated by statistical method and found that these values are in agreement with the derived reactivity ratios.</jats:p>

Title: Complex radical copolymerization of di‐n‐butylstannyl dimethacrylate with maleic anhydride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Mechanisms of radical copolymerization of di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylstannyl dimethacrylate with maleic anhydride in the presence of 2,2‐asobisisobutyronitrile are discussed. Complexing (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>eq</jats:sub>) and copolymerization (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) constants have been determined. Quantitative contributions of cyclization and complexing to reactivity ratios of the monomers under study and to propagation reactions have been estimated. The copolymerization has been found to proceed predominantly at the complex radical cyclocopolymerization step, leading to cyclized and linear unsaturated units in the macromolecule chain.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of cationic monomers with acrylamide in an aqueous solution
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerizations of commercially available cationic monomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with acrylamide (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) have been investigated at pH 6.1 in aqueous solutions. The cationic groups in copolymers were analyzed by a colloid titration method and the reactivity ratios were determined by the Fineman–Ross method. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were 1.71 and 0.25 for methacryloyloxyethyltrimethylammonium chlorideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.68 and 1.26 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminoethylmethacrylateM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.13 and 0.57 for methacrylamidopropyltrimethylammonium chlorideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.10 and 0.47 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminopropylmethacrylateM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 0.47 and 0.95 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminopropylacrylamideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 0.48 and 0.64 for acryloyloxyethyltrimethylammonium chloride‐M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and 0.58 and 6.7 for dimethyldiallylammonium chloride‐M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> systems. The Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were calculated and the linear relationship between log <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and ultraviolet absorption maxima of cationic monomers was found.</jats:p>

Title: Relative reactivity of cis‐ and trans‐1,3‐pentadiene in the cationic copolymerization with isobutene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>‐1,3‐Pentadiene (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) and <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐1,3‐pentadiene (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) were copolymerized with isobutene (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) in the presence of (C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>AlCl+(CH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>CCl or (C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>AlCl+Cl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in the range of temperatures between —35 and —70°C. The reactivity ratios, determined at —55°C, are:<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1.2</jats:sub>=5,0 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1.3</jats:sub>=2,3, while the chain transfer coefficients are <jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>t.2</jats:sub>=50 and <jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>t.3</jats:sub>=113. The activation energies are: <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:styled-content><jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content><jats:sub>v.2</jats:sub>= —13,8kJ/mol (—3,3 kcal/mol) and <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:styled-content><jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content><jats:sub>v.3</jats:sub>= —16,7kJ/mol(—4,0 kcal/mol). Spectroscopic analyses (IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR) showed that in both copolymers the 1,4‐<jats:italic>trans</jats:italic> structure is prevalent over the 1,2‐<jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐enchainment. The fact that <jats:bold>3</jats:bold> is more reactive than <jats:bold>2</jats:bold> can be correlated with a greater electron‐density (<jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR data) on C‐1 in compound <jats:bold>3</jats:bold>.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of the reactivity parameters for the copolymerization of butyl acrylate with vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The composition of vinyl acetate–butyl acrylate copolymers obtained with batch emulsion polymerization have been studied by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR. Using the integrated copolymerization Meyer–Lowry equation, the apparent reactivity ratios of the two monomers were calculated as 10.67 for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, the reactivity ratio of butyl acrylate (BA), and 0.024 for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, the reactivity ratio of vinyl acetate (VAC). These results were compared with those obtained by other methods.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of N‐substituted maleimide with alkyl acrylate and its industrial applications
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A series of new copolymers with desired thermal stability and mechanical properties for applications in leather industry were synthesized from various substituted maleimides and alkyl acrylates. Polymerization was carried out by a free‐radical polymerization using benzoyl peroxide (BPO) as initiator. The monomers and polymers synthesized were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). Interestingly, these polymers were soluble in common organic solvents. Copolymer composition and reactivity ratios were determined by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectra. The molecular weights of the polymers were determined by gel permeation chromatography. The homo‐ and copolymer of maleimide showed single‐stage decomposition (ranging from 300–580°C). The initial decomposition temperatures of poly[<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(phenyl)maleimide] [poly(PM)], poly[<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐4‐(methylphenyl)maleimide] [poly(MPM)] and poly[<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐3‐(chlorophenyl)maleimide] [poly(CPM)] were higher compared to those of the copolymers. Heat‐resistant adhesives such as blends of epoxy resin with phenyl‐substituted maleimide<jats:italic>‐co‐</jats:italic>glycidyl methacrylate copolymers with improved adhesion property were developed. Different adhesive formulations of these copolymaleimides were prepared by curing with diethanolamine at two different temperatures (30°C and 60°C). © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 80: 1870–1879, 2001</jats:p>

Title: Graft copolymerization of poly(styrene‐co‐p‐choloromethylstyrene) with methyl methacrylate and acryloylmorpholine by atom transfer radical polymerization: Graft copolymer characterization and monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Poly[styrene‐<jats:italic>graft</jats:italic>‐(acryloylmorpholine‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐methyl methacrylate)] graft copolymers in various compositions, poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>graft</jats:italic>‐acryloylmorpholine), and poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>graft</jats:italic>‐methyl methacrylate) were prepared by atom transfer radical polymerization with poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chloromethylstyrene) (62/38) as the macroinitiator in the presence of CuBr/1,2‐dipiperidinoethane at 130 °C in <jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide. The graft copolymers were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR, and differential scanning calorimetry. The thermal stabilities of the graft copolymers were investigated by thermogravimetric analysis. The monomer reactivity ratios in the graft copolymerization of acryloylmorpholine (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were calculated by the application of linear methods, such as the Finemann–Ross, inverted Finemann–Ross, Yezrielev–Brokhina–Roskin, Kelen–Tüdos, and extended Kelen–Tüdos methods, and the Mayo–Lewis method, which uses an integrated copolymer equation in a terminal model of copolymerization. <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> was 1.13–2.11, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was 0.49–1.05, according to the various methods. The Yezrielev–Brokhina–Roskin method gave the best linearity for the experimental results, and the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values were 1.28 and 0.54, respectively. © 2005 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 43: 3771–3777, 2005</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis of imide‐based methacrylic monomers and their copolymerization with methyl methacrylate: monomer reactivity ratios and heat resistance properties
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The newly designed methacrylic monomer series 4‐phthalimidocyclohexyl methacrylate (PCMA<jats:bold>),</jats:bold> 4‐hexahydrophthalimidocyclohexyl methacrylate (HPCMA) and 4‐hexahydro‐3,6‐methanophthalimidocyclohexyl methacrylate (HMPCMA) were synthesized. Their homopolymers and methyl methacrylate (MMA) based copolymer series were polymerized by free‐radical polymerization. The copolymer compositions were characterized using <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectra. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated employing the Fineman−Ross (F‐T) and Kelen−Tüdös (K‐T) methods at low conversion. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> obtained by the F‐T and K‐T methods appear to be in close agreement (their average values are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.3061 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.7336 for poly(PCMA‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐MMA), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.5169 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.6840 for poly(HPCMA‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐MMA), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.7748 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.5664 for poly(HMPCMA‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐MMA)) . The thermal stabilities and thermomechanical characteristics of the homopolymer and copolymer series were investigated by differential scanning calorimetry, thermogravimetric analysis and dynamic mechanical thermal analysis. © 2018 Society of Chemical Industry</jats:p>

Title: Statistical group transfer copolymerization. Monomer reactivity ratios for allyl methacrylate and n-butyl methacrylate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Solvent effect in radical copolymerization of styrene with p‐aminostyrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐Aminostyrene (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>, M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were radically copolymerized at 60°C in various solvents. There is a significant solvent effect on monomer reactivity ratios, especially on <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, suggesting a specific interaction between the solvent and the polymer radical with the <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐aminostyrene moiety at the terminal position. In order to clarify the solvent factor influencing the relative reactivity, the hydrogen‐bond‐accepting basicity of the solvent (β) was determined from enhanced UV shifts for <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> relative to <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethyl‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐aminostyrene. Regression analysis of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> with the solvatochromic parameters revealed that β is the major factor responsible for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>‐variations.</jats:p>

Title: Redox‐initiated radical polymerization of 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate, 3. Copolymerization with nine monomers, effect of structure and media on the reactivity of monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) with eight acrylic monomers and vinyl acetate using redox initiators was carried out in DMF and in aqueous medium. Reactivity ratios were calculated according to the general copolymerization equation using Fineman‐Ross, Kelen‐Tüdős and the YBR methods. The results indicate that reactivity of the methacrylates towards growing HEMA radicals decreased in the order, methyl methacrylate > 2‐dimethylaminoethyl methacrylate > 2,3‐epoxypropyl methacrylate. Reactivity of the acrylates decreased in the order butyl acrylate > ethyl acrylate > methyl acrylate. In the HEMA‐acrylate systems, the intrinsic viscosity of the copolymers decreased with increasing content of the acrylates in the copolymer. On the other hand, the intrinsic viscosity of the copolymers of HEMA‐MMA showed an increasing trend with increasing content of MMA in the copolymer. Changing the polymerization medium from DMF to water resulted in copolymers having a higher HEMA content.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer apparent reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile/methyl vinyl ketone copolymerization system
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Methyl vinyl ketone was firstly used to successfully copolymerize with acrylonitrile. This was achieved by using azobisisobutyronitrile as the initiator, and dimethyl sulfoxide as the solvent. Effect of copolymerization systems on monomer apparent reactivity ratios for copolymer of acrylonitrile with methyl vinyl ketone was studied for contrast. Values of monomer apparent reactivity ratios were calculated by Kelen–Tudos method. It has been found that the apparent reactivity ratios in aqueous suspension polymerization system were similar to those in solution polymerization system at polymerization conversion less than 20%. Beyond 50% of conversion, the changes of monomer apparent reactivity ratios become less prominent. In water‐rich reaction medium [(H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O/dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO)>80/20), monomer apparent reactivity ratios were approximately equivalent to those in aqueous suspension polymerization system. In DMSO‐rich reaction medium (DMSO/H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O > 80/20), apparent reactivity ratios were similar to those in solution polymerization system. Values of apparent reaction ratios both decreased when AN/MVK copolymer was synthesized in DMF and DMAc. The values of apparent reaction ratios gradually tend to 1 with increasing the copolymerization temperature. © 2006 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 102: 4045–4048, 2006</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and polymerization studies of some N‐alkylol acrylamides. II. Polymerization and copolymerization of 2‐methacrylamido‐2‐hydroxymethyl‐1,3‐propanediole
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A study has been made of the radical polymerization and copolymerization of 2‐methacrylamido‐2‐hydroxymethyl‐1,3‐propanediole with styrene at 60°C. This monomer homopolymerizes easily in water solution, yielding polymers of high molecular weight, but at high conversion crosslinking occurs. A further detailed kinetic investigation in dimethylformamide resulted in values for the overall rate of polymerization that were comparable to values for other acryl monomers. For copolymerization of 2‐methacrylamido‐2‐hydroxymethyl‐1,3‐propanediole (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) in dimethylformamide solution, the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.47 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.29 were obtained.</jats:p>

Title: Anionic copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Previous work with anionic copolymerizations held that the terminal carbanion played no role in determining which monomer was next added. Recent work by Graham et al. has demonstrated that this is untrue for monomers of extremely dissimilar polarities. In this paper the kinetics of copolymerization of dissimilar monomers has been developed. As a result it is shown that the ratio of monomers in the initial copolymer <jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] is directly proportional to the square of the initial monomer ratio ([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> when the monomers are dissimilar. The earlier theory resulted in a first‐power proportionality for all cases. Log—log plots of the equation <jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] = <jats:italic>K</jats:italic>([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])<jats:italic><jats:sup>a</jats:sup></jats:italic> show that <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> has a value of 2.0 for styrene—methyl methacrylate, 1.0 for styrene—isoprene and 1.3 for methyl methacrylate—methacrylonitrile. The conclusion is drawn that values of <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> of 1.0 and 2.0 represent extremes of behavior for monomers of very similar and very dissimilar polarites. As a corollary of this it is concluded that reactivity ratios for these systems where <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> is not 1.0 are of questionable theoretical significance.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of methyl methacrylate with methacrylic monomers derived from salicylic acid. Microstructural analysis, chain flexibility and hydration behaviour of the prepared copolymers
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Effect of reaction medium on copolymerization of acrylonitrile and methyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of acrylonitrile (AN) with methyl acrylate (MEA) has been investigated in three types of polymerization, i.e., emulsion polymerization in water with a water‐soluble initiator, suspension polymerization in water with an oil‐soluble and water‐insoluble initiator, and solution polymerization in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). Monomer reactivity ratios at 50°C. for AN and MEA are found to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.78 ± 0.02, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.04 ± 0.02 in emulsion polymerization; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.02 ± 0.02, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.70 ± 0.02 in DMSO solution polymerization; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.75 ± 0.05, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.54 ± 0.05 in suspension polymerization. The large differences found in the reactivity ratios may be attributed to the different ratio of concentration of two monomers in the loci of polymerization. Chemically, AN is somewhat more reactive than MEA as shown by the reactivity ratios in DMSO. In the case of the suspension polymerization, the MEA/AN ratio in the polymer particles in which polymerization occurs may be higher than that in the total phase. Experimental results of the emulsion polymerization show that the emulsion polymerization of AN occurs both in the particles and in water. In addition, rates of the copolymerization of AN with MEA have also been investigated.</jats:p>

Title: Analysis of the linear methods of determining copolymerization reactivity ratios, 9. Penultimate systems with r2 = 0
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization equation considering the penultimate unit effect, the so called penultimate model, takes a simplified shape in the case of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 (monomer 2, M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, does not homopolymerize). For this case a method analogous to the conventional KT(Kelen‐Tüdős)‐transformation for estimation of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ is proposed. The new method was verified by literature data for the system styrene/fumarodinitrile, polymerized with benzoyl peroxide at 70°C, yielding <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,062 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ = 0,812. Classification of copolymerization curves by means of the classical copolymerization model permits to distinguish between three curve‐types: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> < 2 (alternation with respect to M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2 (linear diagram with slope 0,5) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> > 2 (non alternating system). The penultimate model permits to generate further curve‐types of “S”‐shape with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> > 2 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ > 2 or <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> > 2 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ < 2 (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ for classically behaving systems and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ≠ <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ for non‐classically behaving systems).</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerization of α‐methylene‐γ‐butyrolactone
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of α‐methylene‐γ‐butyrolactone (α‐MBL) homopolymerization was investigated in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide (DMF) with azobis(isobutyronitrile) as initiator. The rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) was expresed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.54</jats:sup>[α‐MBL]<jats:sup>1.1</jats:sup> and the overall activation energy was calculated as 76.1 kJ/mol. Kinetic constants for α‐MBL polymerization were obtained as follows: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub><jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> = 0.161 L<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> mol<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>·s<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>; 2<jats:italic>fk</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>d</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 2.18 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The relative reactivity ratios of α‐MBL(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.14, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.87) were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 2.2 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.65. These <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for α‐MBL are higher than those for MMA</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic study of the stable free‐radical copolymerization of styrene with butyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of styrene and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate mediated by 1‐phenyl‐1‐(2′,2′,6′,6′‐tetramethyl‐1′‐piperidinyl‐oxy)ethane in bulk at 125 °C has been analyzed over a wide range of conversions and monomer feed compositions. Monomer reactivity ratios have been determined, and the Mayo–Lewis terminal model provides excellent predictions for the variations of the intermolecular structure over the entire conversion range. The kinetic analysis of this copolymerization system indicates an apparent propagation rate coefficient independent of the monomer feed composition as well as a limiting conversion that decreases as the styrene monomer feed decreases. This fact is attributed to side reactions leading to unsaturated end groups and the accumulation of nonactive adducts of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate. The number‐average molecular weights linearly increase with conversion, and the copolymers present narrow molecular weight distributions. © 2002 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 40: 2750–2758, 2002</jats:p>

Title: A Linearization Procedure for the Determination of the Radical Reactivity Ratios in Restricted Penultimate Copolymerization Systems
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A newly developed method for the determination of the radical reactivity ratios is presented. Two main equations are used and the parameters can be calculated from the ordinate and the slope of the linearization plots. Both equations yield identical values when applied to synthetic data which conforms to the ideal situation of no error in the input data. As experimental data are always subject to some kind of error, a sensitivity analysis was carried out which took into account a relatively pronounced error in the monomer reactivity ratios. It turned out that the new linearization method may even be indicative of the quality of the input data under favorable conditions.</jats:p><jats:p><jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text>
</jats:p>

Title: High temperature bulk copolymerization of methyl methacrylate and acrylonitrile. I. Reactivity ratio estimation
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of methyl methacrylate and acrylonitrile has been studied in the bulk phase. Experiments for estimating reactivity ratios were conducted at 60, 100, 120, and 140°C. Tidwell–Mortimer and the feed composition constraint approaches were used to design the experiments. The error in variables model (EVM) method was employed to evaluate the reactivity ratios and analyze the error involved. The results show that the reactivity ratios do not vary significantly with temperature up to 140°C. © 2006 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 100: 843–851, 2006</jats:p>

Title: Experimental methods and data evaluation procedures for the determination of radical copolymerization reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Reactivity ratios and sequence structures of the copolymers prepared using photo‐induced copolymerization of MMA with MTMP
Abstract: <jats:p>4‐Methacryloyl‐2,2,6,6‐tetramethyl‐piperidine (MTMP) was applied as reactive hindered amine piperidine. Photo‐induced copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA, <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with MTMP (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was carried out in benzene solution at ambient temperature. The reactivity ratios for these monomers were measured by running a series of reactions at various feed ratios of initial monomers, and the monomer incorporation into copolymer was determined using <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR. Reactivity ratios of the MMA/MTMP system were measured to be <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.37 and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.14 from extended Kelen‐Tüdos method. The results show that monomer MTMP prefers homopolymerization to copolymerization in the system, whereas monomer MMA prefers copolymerization to homopolymerization. Sequence structures of the MMA/MTMP copolymers were characterized using <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR. The results show that the sequence structure for the main chain of the MMA/MTMP copolymers is mainly composed of a syndiotactic configuration, only with a little heterotactic configuration. Three kinds of the sequences of <jats:italic>rr</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>rr</jats:italic>′, and <jats:italic>lr</jats:italic>′ in the syndiotactic configuration are found. The sequence‐length distribution in the MMA/MTMP copolymers is also obtained. For <jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.2, the monomer unit of MMA is mostly separated by MTMP units, and for <jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.6, the alternating tendency prevails and a large number of mono‐sequences are formed; further up to <jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.8, the monomer unit of MTMP with the sequence of one unit is interspersed among the chain of MMA. Copyright © 2012 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of methacrylaldehyde with hydrophilic monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of methacrylaldehyde with hydrophilic monomers — 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate, 5‐hydroxy‐3‐oxapentyl methacrylate, 8‐hydroxy‐3,6‐dioxaoctyl methacrylate, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ethylmethacrylamide, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐diethylacrylamide, and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐diethylmethacrylamide — were prepared by solution polymerization in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide initiated with 2,2′‐azodiisobutyronitrile. In the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde (1) with 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (2) (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,77, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,36) and in the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐diethylacrylamide (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3,79, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,14) the content of CHO groups corresponds to that ot methacrylaldehyde units in the triads comonomer — methacrylaldehyde — comonomer; in the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ethylmethacrylamide (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 4,07, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,14) both comonomers react with each other and the content of CHO groups is very low, while in the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde with 5‐hydroxy‐3‐oxapentyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1,48, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,34) the majority of methacrylaldehyde units contain an unreacted CHO group.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization reactivity ratios analysis of sequentially sampled data by error in variables method
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A new method for estimating copolymerization reactivity ratios, by sequentially sampling the reaction medium and analyzing the samples by ultraviolet spectroscopy and gravimetry, was developed. The data were analyzed by a new error‐in‐variables method. The method was applied to solution copolymerization of the styrene (Sty)–methyl methacrylate (MMA) system in butyl acetate at 65°C, for which reactivity ratios were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0.660 ± 0.050 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Sty</jats:sub> = 0.309 ± 0.050. The data were also analyzed by the Kelen–Tüdös and the Extended Kelen–Tüdös methods where the methods are applicable. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 95: 393–399, 2005</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics of the radical copolymerization of 2,2,2‐trifluoroethyl methacrylate with tert‐butyl α‐trifluoromethacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of two different methacrylate monomers, 2,2,2‐trifluoroethyl methacrylate (TFEMA) and <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl α‐trifluoromethacrylate (TBTFMA) in solution was investigated. The resulting statistic poly(TFEMA‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐TBTFMA) copolymers were characterized by NMR spectroscopy to assess their compositions. The kinetics of copolymerization enabled one to determine the reactivity ratios of both comonomers according to the methods of Fineman‐Ross, Kelen‐Tüdos, and extended Kelen‐Tüdos. Excellent correlations were found between these methods leading to the following reactivity ratios: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>TFEMA</jats:sub> = 4.87 ± 1.50 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>TBTFMA</jats:sub> = 0.10 ± 0.02 at 74 °C. These values indicated that the structure of the copolymers was composed of poly(TFEMA) micro‐blocks separated by one TBTFMA unit. Both yields and molecular weights (ranging between 1,000 and 12,000 g/mol) increased with the TFEMA content. The thermal stability of these (co)polymers showed that the decomposition temperature at 10% weight loss increased both with TFEMA content and increasing molecular weights of the poly(TFEMA‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐TBTFMA) copolymers. © 2010 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 48: 1029–1037, 2010</jats:p>

Title: A method of calculating copolymerization reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>An improved linearization method is proposed for determining the monomer reactivity ratios of free‐radical copolymerizations by fitting the data of cumulative copolymer compositions and overall weight fractional conversions, or cumulative copolymer compositions and residual monomer compositions of the reaction mixture. The reactivity ratios of monomers for four different copolymerization reactions are determined. The results are very close to those of literature reports and account well for the experimental results.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of N-[3-dialkylaminopropyl]methacrylamides with acrylic amides and esters in organic solvents
Abstract: <jats:p>The radical copolymerization of N-[3-(dialkylamino)-propyl]methacrylamides with a number of (meth)acrylic amides and esters in organic solvents over a wide range of molar ratios has been studied. Co-polymerisation constants for five polymerisation systems in 1,4-dioxane and toluene have been determined by the Feinman and Ross method. The influence of the solvent on the kinetics of the copolymerization of the studied monomers was found, which manifests itself in a change of the reactivity ratios of the monomers upon varying the polarity of the medium. For the obtained polymers, the presence of thermosensitive properties in aqueous solutions and the effect of the concentration and composition of copolymers on their solubility in water were shown.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios from copolymerization kinetics. A quantitative gas-liquid chromatography experiment
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Monomers reactivity ratios of fluorinated acrylates–styrene copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerizations of styrene and 2‐<jats:italic>F</jats:italic>‐hexylethyl acrylate, 4‐<jats:italic>F</jats:italic>‐hexylbutyl acrylate and 6‐<jats:italic>F</jats:italic>‐hexylhexyl acrylate were conducted by free radical polymerization in acetonitrile at 80 °C using AIBN as initiator. The reactivity ratios of the three systems were determined by the Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdos methods. Consequently, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values have been calculated by the Alfrey and Price method. We found that the spacer length between the fluorinated chain and the ester function has no influence on the reactivity of our fluorinated monomers. Comparison of these results with those described in the literature for hydrocarbon homologous confirmed the reactivity scale.</jats:p><jats:p>© 2002 Society of Chemical Industry</jats:p>

Title: Semicontinuous emulsion copolymerization of acrylonitrile, butyl acrylate, and styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Semicontinuous emulsion copolymerization of acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), butyl acrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), and styrene (M<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) was investigated. The copolymerization proceeded under the conditions used with a high degree of conversion, whereby a stationary state characterized by a constant monomer mixture composition and a constant composition of the arising copolymer was achieved. From the analytically estimated free monomers and arising copolymer compositions, the reactivity ratios for the pair AN/BA <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 0.71, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 1.17 and for the pair AN/Sty <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>13</jats:sub> = 0.06, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>31</jats:sub> = 0.28 were calculated. The applicability of the reactivity ratios found was verified also for the ternary system acrylonitrile/butyl acrylate/styrene.</jats:p>
