Title: Radical‐Initiated homopolymerization and copolymerization of methylthiomethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Methylthiomethyl methacrylate (MtMA) was synthesized and homopolymerized in solution. The poly(MtMA) is readily soluble in benzene, acetone, tetrahydrofuran, and methylene chloride at room temperature. The values of <jats:italic>K</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> in the Mark–Houwink equation, [η] = <jats:italic>KM</jats:italic><jats:sup><jats:italic>a</jats:italic></jats:sup>, were found to be <jats:italic>K</jats:italic> = 2.88 × 10<jats:sup>–5</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> = 0.75 when <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> = <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>w</jats:italic></jats:sub>. The glass transition temperature of poly(MtMA) was observed to be 72°C by thermomechanical analysis. Intramolecular anhydride formation occurred when poly(MtMA) was heated to 250–300°C. The kinetics of MtMA homopolymerization was investigated in benzene, using azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The rate of polymerization <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> was expressed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.5</jats:sup>[MtMA]<jats:sup>1.05</jats:sup> and the overall activation energy was calculated to be 75.7 kJ/mol. The relative reactivity ratios of MtMA in styrene copolymerizations (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>1</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 0.33, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>2</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 0.55) were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> scheme led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 1.07 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.51 for MtMA.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of 4-Acetylphenyl Methacrylate with Ethyl Methacrylate: Synthesis, Characterization, Monomer Reactivity Ratios, and Thermal Properties
Abstract: <jats:p>Methacrylates have high glass transition temperature (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M1"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mi>T</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>g</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:math>) values and high thermal stability. A new methacrylate copolymer, poly(4-acetylphenyl methacrylate-co-ethyl methacrylate) (APMA-co-EMA), was synthesized. The thermal behaviors of copolymers were investigated by differential scanning calorimetry and thermogravimetric analysis. They behaved as new single polymers with single<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M2"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mi>T</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>g</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:math>’s and the thermal stability of the copolymers increased with increasing 4-acetylphenyl methacrylate (APMA) fraction, leading to the manufacture of copolymers with desired<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M3"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mi>T</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>g</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:math>values. Structure and composition of copolymers for a wide range of monomer feed ratios were determined by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) and<jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H-nuclear magnetic resonance (<jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H-NMR) spectroscopic techniques. Copolymerization reactions were continued up to 40% conversions. The monomer reactivity ratios for copolymer system were determined by the Kelen-Tüdös (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M4"><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mi>a</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mtext>APMA</mml:mtext></mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:mrow></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0.81</mml:mn></mml:math>;<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M5"><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mi>b</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mtext>EMA</mml:mtext></mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:mrow></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0.61</mml:mn></mml:math>) and extended Kelen-Tüdös (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M6"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mi>a</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0.77</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math>;<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M7"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mi>b</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0.54</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math>) methods and a nonlinear least squares (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M8"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mi>a</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0.74</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math>;<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M9"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mi>b</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0.49</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math>) method.</jats:p>

Title: The mechanism of vinyl polymerization initiated by metal alkyls: Copolymerization studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios have been determined for the copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) catalyzed by alkyl derivatives of lithium, sodium, beryllium, magnesium, boron, aluminum, zinc, and cadmium. Lithium, sodium, beryllium, and magnesium alkyls gave reactivity ratios averaging <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.34, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 6.7, while alkyls of boron, aluminum, zinc, and cadmium gave <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.24, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.11. These values compare favorably with published reactivity ratios for anionic copolymerization (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.25, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 7.9) and free‐radical copolymerization (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.35, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.18). Therefore, alkyl derivatives of groups Ia and IIa metals propagate by an anionic mechanism, while those of groups IIb and IIIa do so by a free‐radical mechanism. Confirmatory experiments were run using styrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) solutions. For groups Ia and IIa alkyls the reactivity ratios averaged, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.20, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 12.5; and for Groups IIb and IIIa <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.33, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.03. The published values for free‐radical catalysts are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.41, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.04. The formation of free radicals from the groups IIb and IIIa metal alkyls probably arises from oxidation of the metal alkyls by chance traces of oxygen.</jats:p>

Title: Studies on the copolymerization of methyl methacrylate with N‐(o/m/p‐chlorophenyl) itaconimides
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The article describes the synthesis and characterization of N‐aryl itaconimide monomers such as: N‐(<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chlorophenyl) itaconimide (PI)/N‐(<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐chlorophenyl) itaconimide (MI)/N‐(<jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorophenyl) itaconimide (OI) and its copolymerization behavior with MMA. The homopolymers and copolymers of N‐aryl itaconimides and methyl methacrylate (MMA, M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were synthesized by varying the mol fraction of N‐aryl itaconimides in the initial feed from 0.1 to 0.5 using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator and tetrahydrofuran (THF) as the solvent. Copolymer composition was determined using <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy [by taking the ratio of intensities of signals due to OCH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> of MMA (δ = 3.59 ppm) and the aromatic proton (δ = 7.2–7.5 ppm) of N‐aryl itaconimides] and percent nitrogen content. The reactivity ratios were found to be r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.33 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.36 (PI‐MMA) <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.15 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.32 (MI‐MMA) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.81 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.35 (OI‐MMA). Molecular weight as determined using high‐performance liquid chromatography decreased with increasing mol fraction of itaconimides in copolymers. All the polymers had a polydisperstivity index in the range of 1.5–2.6.Thermal characterization was done using differential scanning calorimetry and dynamic thermogravimetry in nitrogen atmosphere. Incorporation of these N‐aryl itaconimides in PMMA backbone resulted in an improvement in glass transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and thermal stability. Percent char increased with the increase of PI/MI/OI content in the copolymers. © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 82: 2078–2086, 2001</jats:p>

Title: Non‐uniqueness in determination of terminal and penultimate model reactivity ratios in the styrene‐methyl methacrylate free‐radical copolymerization system
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The terminal and penultimate model reactivity ratios in the free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate in bulk at 40°C were calculated by means of the simplex and scanning methods. Calculations showed that for the terminal model <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> vary in comparatively narrow ranges of 0.548–0.552 and 0.480–0.483, respectively. For the penultimate model, the most accurate reactivity ratios calculated by the simplex method, which were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub> = 0.727, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub> = 0.490, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 2.890, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 4.583, are surrounded with sets of reactivity ratio values of equal accuracy. The ranges of variation were found to be 0.711–0.746, 0.487–0.492, 2.810–2.970 and 4.213–5.049, respectively. Numerical values of the penultimate <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>‐parameters calculated with the simplex method depend, due to the structure of the multidimensional space (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>, σ), on the initial guess for the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>‐parameters. Use of the covariance matrix for the estimation of the indetermination ranges is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Research in the field of terpolymers. I. Copolymerization of acrylonitrile/methaerylic acid/methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>It is known that copolymerization reactions permit the extension of the scope of monomer utilizations, and especially, the controlled modification of the physico‐chemical and mechanical properties of polymers. Many types of elastomers, plastics and synthetic fibers are synthetized at present on the basis of such a reaction.</jats:p><jats:p>In the last years the field of synthetic fibres has acquired an ever wider utilization together with other groups of spinning polymers as, for instance, the polyamides and polyesters, the acrylic and vinylic copolymers where acrylonitrile is the main component, thanks to the properties it imparts on the polymers.</jats:p><jats:p>The kinetics of the copolymerization of the ternary system acrylonitrile/methacrylic acid/methyl methacrylate is studied. The polymerization was carried out in inert medium and homogeneous phase (solvent: ethylene glycole carbonate) using lauryl peroxide as initiator.</jats:p><jats:p>The authors investigated the variation of copolymer composition as compared to the initial monomer ratios at different conversions and depending on polymerization conditions.</jats:p><jats:p>For the calculation of the composition at a high degree of conversion the monomer reactivities were determined at 70°C by using F<jats:sc>INEMAN</jats:sc>‐R<jats:sc>OSS</jats:sc>, M<jats:sc>AYO</jats:sc>‐L<jats:sc>EWIS</jats:sc>, and J<jats:sc>OSHI</jats:sc>‐K<jats:sc>APUR</jats:sc>, relations. Some discrepancies in the results obtained by each of these methods are discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of copolymerization parameters of methyl methacrylate with dodecyl methacrylate by means of FTIR spectroscopy
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The bulk copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) with dodecyl methacrylate (DMA) initiated by 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) at 60°C was used to prepare samples with different MMA/DMA ratios. The composition of the copolymers was determined by means of FTIR spectroscopy, using the absorption intensity ratio of CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/CO for copolymers in CDCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> solution and as KBr tablets. Reactivity ratios, determined by the Kelen‐Tüdős method, were found to be: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 1.58 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>DMA</jats:sub> = 1.88 for copolymers analyzed in solution, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 1.67 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>DMA</jats:sub> = 1.95 for samples prepared as KBr tablets. Comparison of copolymer composition of some samples was made with elemental analysis data. It was found that the shift in the CO maximum observed for the copolymer in CDCI<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> solution, compared to the corresponding homopolymer solutions, could also be used for determining copolymer composition.</jats:p>

Title: Copper catalyzed atom transfer radical copolymerization of glycidyl methacrylate and 2‐ethylhexyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This investigation reports the atom transfer radical copolymerization (ATRcP) of glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) and 2‐ethylhexyl acrylate (EHA). Poly(glycidyl methacrylate) (PGMA) has easily transformable pendant oxirane group and poly(2‐ethylhexyl acrylate) (PEHA) has very low <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>. They are the important components of coating and adhesive materials. Copolymerization of GMA and EHA was carried out in bulk and in toluene at 70 °C at different molar feed ratios using CuCl as catalyst in combination with 2,2′‐bypyridine (bpy) as well as <jats:italic>N,N,N′,N″,N″</jats:italic>‐pentamethyl diethylenetriamine (PMDETA) as ligand. The molecular weight (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>n</jats:sub>) and the polydispersity index (PDI) of the polymers were determined by GPC analysis. The molar composition of the copolymers was determined by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR analysis. The reactivity ratios of GMA (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and EHA (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were determined using Finemann‐Ross and Kelen‐Tudos linearization methods and those had been compared with the literature values for conventional free radical copolymerization. The thermal properties of the copolymers were studied by DSC and TGA analysis. © 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 47: 6526–6533, 2009</jats:p>

Title: On the origin and consequences of high DMAEMA reactivity ratio in ATRP copolymerization with MMA: An experimental and theoretical study<sup>#</sup>
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Designing and tuning a copolymerization process to obtain specific material properties is still fundamentally empirical and requires the determination of apparent reactivity ratios<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sup>s</jats:sup>. To this end, PEG–(MMA–DMAEMA)<jats:sub>n</jats:sub>copolymers obtained via ATRP of MMA and DMAEMA using a PEG‐based initiator in toluene were analyzed to extract monomer relative reactivities; the impact of changing solvent on the latter was also tested. Differing from previous free radical and controlled radical copolymerizations (CRcoP), we found that DMAEMA is preferentially included (<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/pola29017-math-0001.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0887624X:media:pola29017:pola29017-math-0001"/>and<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/pola29017-math-0002.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0887624X:media:pola29017:pola29017-math-0002"/>) in toluene; increasing the solvent polarity decreased the gap between<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sup>s</jats:sup>. With these data, kMC simulations based on the copolymerization<jats:italic>terminal model</jats:italic>were used to investigate copolymer microstructure, which is not amenable to NMR investigation. kMC simulations evidenced both a gradient‐like nature of the copolymers and a somewhat unexpected qualitative change in the probability of finding MMA‐rich triads along the chain depending on initial feed composition. An additional DFT analysis suggested the likely formation of a DMAEMA:CuBr:2‐2′‐bipyridine complex, which being involved in the regeneration of reactive radicals from dormant species, is expected to locally increase DMAEMA concentration favoring its addition to the growing chains. The formation of such complex is also supported by<jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR experiments. © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Polym. Sci., Part A: Polym. Chem.<jats:bold>2018</jats:bold>,<jats:italic>56</jats:italic>, 1366–1382</jats:p>

A heretofore unrecognized possibility for approaching the problem of general monomer reactivity relationships appears to lie in the consideration of terpolymers. The relationship between monomer and terpolymer compositions is given by the equations

This relationship is shown to hold for a wide range of monomer types and concentrations. The overall probability of initiating a, c, and b sequences immediately preceded by b, a, and c, respectively, and of undefined terminating units is equal to the probability of terminating a, c, and b sequences with b, a, and c units, respectively, but of undefined initiating units. This relationship of product probabilities is as follows:

Methods are presented for predicting the behavior of monomers A and C in copolymerization when the behaviors of A‐B and B‐C are known. Furthermore, it is shown that the value of eq. (3) is frequently in the range of 0.02–0.06. Application of this relationship allows the calculation of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>13</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>31</jats:sub> where <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>23</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>32</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> are known.</jats:p>

Title: Effects of temperature on styrene–methacrylonitrile copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and methacrylonitrile was studied in toluene solution at 60, 90, and 120°C. Copolymer composition was estimated from gas‐chromatographic measurement of unreacted monomer concentrations. Reactions were carried to about 20% conversion to minimize analytical errors. Reactivity ratios were calculated by using an integrated form of the Mayo‐Lewis simple copolymerization equation. Reactivity ratios were not sensitive to reaction temperature. The values at 90°C are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.41 (methacrylonitrile) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.37 (styrene). The <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> values are higher than those reported by other workers, presumably because of advantages in the present analytical technique and calculation method. The negligible temperature dependence of reactivity ratios is in accord with theory. If monomer pairs exhibit pronounced dependence of reactivity ratios on polymerization temperature, this may indicate a change in mode of placement of units in the polymer chain.</jats:p>

Title: Zirconocene‐catalyzed copolymerization of methyl methacrylate with other methacrylate monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Statistical copolymers of methyl methacrylate (MMA) with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl‐, <jats:italic>s</jats:italic>‐butyl, <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐butyl‐, <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐hexyl‐, decyl‐, stearyl‐, allyl‐, trimethylsilyl‐ and trimethylsilyloxyethyl methacrylate were prepared by zirconocene‐catalyzed copolymerization. The reactivity ratios of MMA copolymers with butyl‐, hexyl‐, and stearyl methacrylate were estimated using the Finemann–Ross, the inverted Finemann–Ross, and the Kelen–Tüdos graphical methods. Structural parameters of the copolymers were obtained from the calculated dyad sequences, derived by using the reactivity ratios. The effect of the nature of the methacrylate ester group and the catalytic system used on the copolymer structure is discussed. The glass‐transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>) values of MMA copolymers with butyl‐ and hexyl methacrylate were measured and examined in the frame of several theoretical equations, allowing the prediction of these <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub> values. The best fit was obtained using Barton and Johnston equations, taking the monomer sequence distribution of the copolymers into account. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 42: 3761–3774, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Novel acrylic macromonomer with amphiphilic character derived from Triton X‐100: Radical copolymerization with methyl methacrylate and thermal properties
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article explores the synthesis of a novel methacrylic macromonomer with an amphiphilic character derived from poly(ethylene glycol) <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐octylphenyl ether (MT) and its respective homopolymer. To know their reactivity in radical copolymerization reactions with methyl methacrylate (MMA), a model monomer (MTm) was synthesized to determine the reactivity ratios and compare them with the low molar fractions of copolymers of MT with MMA because they were difficult to isolate. They were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MTm</jats:sub> = 0.97 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0.95. The compositional diagrams when representing the weight fraction of MT and MTm in the feed and the copolymer suggested that a clear correlation exists between the experimental points of the model monomer MTm and the macromonomer MT ones, suggesting that the length of the side poly(ethylene oxide) chain does not affect the reactivity of the methacrylic double bond in the prepared monomers for this type of polymerization reaction. The reactivity ratios of the copolymers have a tendency for the formation of random or Bernoullian copolymers. The glass‐transition temperatures (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>'s) of the prepared copolymers were determined by differential scanning calorimetry, deviated from the Fox equation, and discussed on the basis of treatments that consider the influence of the monomeric units along the copolymer chains, determining the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub> of the corresponding alternating dyads. © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 41: 1641–1649, 2003</jats:p>
